subsection.title: Nilpotent matrices
subsection.p: First, we establish the pattern we've seen so many times in this chapter already.

statement.p: A scalar-triangular matrix A with \lambda = 0 down the main diagonal will satisfy A^n = 0, where n is the size of A. In particular, such a matrix is always nilpotent.

proof.title: Proof outline
proof.p: We omit a detailed proof, relying on to demonstrate the pattern.

However, a proof by induction is fairly straightforward, as a matrix of this form can be broken up into a block matrix A = \left[\begin{array}{@{}c|c@{}} 0 \amp R \\ \hline \zerovec \amp B \end{array}\right] , where B is an (n-1) \times (n-1) matrix of the same form, R is a 1 \times (n-1) row vector, and \zerovec represents an (n-1) \times 1 zero vector. Using the pattern of block multiplication from , one can calculate A^k = \left[\begin{array}{@{}c|c@{}} 0 \amp RB^{k-1} \\ \hline \zerovec \amp B^k \end{array}\right] for any positive exponent k, and from there the result follows readily using the appropriate induction hypothesis.

subsection.p: Despite the lemma above, keep in mind here a matrix does not have to be triangular to be nilpotent.

proposition.title: Eigenvalues and characteristic polynomial of nilpotent

statement.p: A nilpotent matrix always has only a single eigenvalue \lambda = 0, and its characteristic polynomial must be c(\lambda) = \lambda^n.

proof.p: Suppose A is a square matrix, \lambda = \lambda_0 is an eigenvalue of A, and \uvec{x} is a (nonzero) eigenvector of A corresponding to \lambda_0. For every positive exponent k, we have A^k \uvec{x} = \lambda_0^k \uvec{x} . But if A is nilpotent with A^k = \zerovec for some k, then the above becomes \zerovec = \lambda_0^k \uvec{x} . Since \uvec{x} is assumed nonzero, we must have \lambda_0^k = 0 (Rule of ), which forces \lambda = 0 as well.
We have established that A cannot have any eigenvalues, real or complex, besides \lambda = 0. The assertion that c_A(\lambda) = \lambda^n immediately follows.

subsection.p: A matrix whose powers eventually become zero does not sound like it could be invertible, and that is the case.

statement.p: A nilpotent matrix is always singular.

proof.p: Combine with the equivalence of Statement and Statement in .

subsection.p:
While a matrix does not have to be triangular to be nilpotent, combining the above proposition with
does tell us the following.

corollary.title: Triangular block form of nilpotent matrices

statement.p: Every nilpotent matrix is similar to a scalar-triangular matrix with \lambda = 0 down the main diagonal.

subsection.p: This corollary in turn tells us about the maximum exponent required to take a nilpotent matrix to zero.

statement.p: If A is an n \times n nilpotent matrix, then A^n = \zerovec.

proof.p: By , A is similar to a scalar-triangular matrix T with \lambda = 0 down the main diagonal. Applying to T, we have T^n = \zerovec. But tells us that A^n will be similar to T^n, and the only matrix that is similar to the zero matrix is the zero matrix itself (), from which we can conclude that A^n = \zerovec.

remark.p:
demonstrates that powers of a nilpotent matrix can become zero before the exponent reaches the size of the matrix. We call the first exponent where zero occurs the
of the matrix, a concept that will become important in completing our study of matrix forms.

proposition.title: Similar to nilpotent is nilpotent of same degree

statement.p: A matrix that is similar to a nilpotent one must itself also be nilpotent, and the two similar matrices must have the same degree of nilpotency.

proof.title: Outline of proof
proof.p: Suppose we have a pair of similar matrices. By , these two matrices also have similar powers. Since the only matrix that is similar to the zero matrix is the zero matrix itself, if a power of one of the two matrices becomes zero at a certain power, then so will the other.

subsection.title: The Cayley-Hamilton Theorem
subsection.p:
First, we establish the similarity pattern of matrix polynomials explored in
and discussed in .

lemma.title: Similar matrices evaluate to similar results

statement.p: Suppose p(x) is a polynomial and A and P are square matrices of the same size with P invertible. Then, p(\inv{P} A P) = \inv{P} \bigl(p(A)\bigr) P .

proof.title: Proof outline
proof.p: The case that p(x) consists of just a power of x, so that p(x) = x^k, is proved exactly as in the proof of . And then the case of a general polynomial p(x) = a_0 + a_1 x + a_2 x^2 + \dotsb + a_m x^m follows from single-power case, and is left as an exercise for you, the reader.

subsection.p: Now we'll record and prove the main result of this chapter.

statement.p: For every square matrix A, c_A(A) = \zerovec.

proof.p:
As in , first we will prove the statement in the case that A is a matrix in triangular block form. The eigenvalues of such a matrix are precisely the diagonal entries, and each algebraic multiplicity is equal to the size of the corresponding scalar-triangular block along the block diagonal. So the characteristic polynomial of A will be of the form
c_A(\lambda) = (\lambda - \lambda_1)^{m_1} (\lambda - \lambda_2)^{m_2} \dotsm (\lambda - \lambda_\ell)^{m_\ell} , where we assume that the linear factors appear in the same order according to eigenvalue that the scalar-triangular blocks appear down the block diagonal of A. Evaluating c_A(\lambda) at A gives c_A(A) = (A - \lambda_1 I)^{m_1} (A - \lambda_2 I)^{m_2} \dotsm (A - \lambda_\ell I)^{m_\ell} . Now, each linear expression A - \lambda_j I will also be in triangular block form, but the blocks will now have the differences of eigenvalues against the specific eigenvalue \lambda_j down their main diagonals. In particular, the \nth[j] scalar-triangular block will have zero repeated down the main diagonal. And since that \nth[j] block has size equal to the corresponding algebraic multiplicity m_j, raising it to the exponent m_j will result in the zero matrix (). Applying Statement of , each factor (A - \lambda_j I)^{m_j} will have a zero block, and these will appear in descending positions down the block diagonal from factor to factor as j increases from 1 to \ell. Multiplying these factors together is achieved by multiplying together all the corresponding block matrices from the block diagonals, and this will result in zero for each block position since each such product will have a zero factor in it. Therefore, c_A(A) = \zerovec.

Now we proceed as in . Suppose that A is a general square matrix, not necessarily in any special form. Even if A is a real matrix, we will consider it to be a complex matrix (every real number is also a complex number!), and we will work over the field of scalars \C. implies that every polynomial, considered as a complex polynomial, factors completely into linear factors. (See .) Therefore, the characteristic polynomial of A can be factored completely as in above, and so can be applied to obtain a matrix T in triangular block form to which A is similar. From the first case above, we know c_T(T) = \zerovec . But similar matrices have the same characteristic polynomial () and evaluate to similar results in polynomials (), so c_A(A) is similar to c_T(T) = \zerovec . However, the only matrix that is similar to the zero matrix is the zero matrix itself, so we can conclude that c_A(A) = \zerovec .

subsection.title: More consequences of triangular block form
subsection.p: Finally, we'll record the patterns we discovered in .

theorem.title: Determinant and trace versus characteristic polynomial and eigenvalues

statement.p:
Suppose A is an n \times n matrix.
The determinant of A is equal to the product of its eigenvalues, both real and complex, and with each eigenvalue repeated in the product according to its algebraic multiplicity.
The constant term in the characteristic polynomial of A is always (-1)^n \det A.
The trace of A is equal to the sum of its eigenvalues, both real and complex, and with each eigenvalue repeated in the sum according to its algebraic multiplicity.
The \lambda^{n-1} term in the characteristic polynomial of A always has coefficient - \trace A.

proof.p:
Since similar matrices have the same determinant, trace, characteristic polynomial, and eigenvalues, and since every matrix is similar (over \C) to a matrix in triangular block form, it suffices to consider the case of triangular block form. So suppose A is a triangular block matrix, and its characteristic polynomial factors as a complex polynomial into
c_A(\lambda) = (\lambda - \lambda_1)^{m_1} (\lambda - \lambda_2)^{m_2} \dotsm (\lambda - \lambda_\ell)^{m_\ell} .

The \nth[j] block of A is scalar-triangular with determinant equal to \lambda_j^{m_j}, the product of its diagonal entries. Applying Statement of , we immediately get \det A = \lambda_1^{m_1} \lambda_2^{m_2} \dotsm \lambda_\ell^{m_\ell} . Determining the constant term of c_A(\lambda) is as easy as evaluating the polynomial at \lambda = 0, which yields
c_A(0) \amp = (- \lambda_1)^{m_1} (- \lambda_2)^{m_2} \dotsm (- \lambda_\ell)^{m_\ell} \amp = (-1)^{m_1 + m_2 + \dotsb + m_\ell} \lambda_1^{m_1} \lambda_2^{m_2} \dotsm \lambda_\ell^{m_\ell} \amp = (-1)^n \det A , where m_1 + m_2 + \dotsb + m_\ell = n because the degree of a characteristic polynomial is always equal to the size of the matrix.

Similarly, the trace of the \nth[j] block of A is equal to m_j \lambda_j, the sum of its diagonal entries. The trace of A is then clearly equal to the sum of these sums of diagonal entries, so that \trace A = m_1 \lambda_1 + m_2 \lambda_2 + \dotsb + m_\ell \lambda_\ell . To investigate the coefficient on \lambda^{n-1} in , first consider this expression as c_A(\lambda) = \bigl[(\lambda - \lambda_1) \dotsm (\lambda - \lambda_1)\bigr] \dotsm \bigl[(\lambda - \lambda_\ell) \dotsm (\lambda - \lambda_\ell)\bigr] , where each factor is repeated according to algebraic multiplicity. Similar to how the Binomial Theorem is investigated, in expanding the above expression we get a term involving \lambda^{n-1} by choosing \lambda from all but one of the linear factors and choosing (-\lambda_j) from the remaining factor, and multiplying all these choices together. Each such product will be equal to -\lambda_j \lambda^{n-1}, and we get m_j such terms for each eigenvalue because there are m_j linear factors involving that eigenvalue to end up as the remaining factor in our choices. Collecting these like terms, the coefficient on the term involving \lambda^{n-1} is
- m_1 \lambda_1 - m_2 \lambda_2 - \dotsb - m_\ell \lambda_\ell = - \trace A .
